5    |  **   Providing a flexible user environment				     **
6    |  ** 									     **
7    |  **   File:		getopt.c					     **
8    |  **   First Edition:	1995/12/20					     **

11   |  ** 									     **
12   |  **   Description:	getopt procedure for the Modules package	     **
13   |  ** 									     **
14   |  **   Exports:		getopt		Recognition of commadn line options  **
15   |  ** 									     **
16   |  **   Notes: This is based on the 'Getopt for GNU' from the gcc-2.7.2        **
17   |  **          compiler. It is preferred to the libc version, because it       **
18   |  **	     provides 'long-options'.					     **
19   |  **									     **

58   | /** 				   CONFIGURATION			     **/
59   | /** ************************************************************************ **/
60   | 
61   | /**
62   |  **  This tells Alpha OSF/1 not to define a getopt prototype in <stdio.h>.
63   |  **  Ditto for AIX 3.2 and <stdlib.h>.
64   |  **/
65   | 
66   | #ifndef _NO_PROTO
67   | #  define _NO_PROTO
68   | #endif
69   | 
70   | #ifdef HAVE_CONFIG_H
71   | #  include <config.h>
72   | #endif
73   | 
74   | /**
75   |  **  This is a separate conditional since some stdc systems
76   |  **  reject `defined( const)'. 
77   |  **/
78   | 
79   | #if !defined( __STDC__) || !__STDC__
80   | #  ifndef const
81   | #    define const
82   | #  endif
83   | #endif
84   | 
85   | /** ************************************************************************ **/
86   | /** 				      HEADERS				     **/
87   | /** ************************************************************************ **/
88   | 
89   | #include <stdio.h>
90   | 
91   | /**
92   |  **  Comment out all this code if we are using the GNU C Library, and are not
93   |  **  actually compiling the library itself.  This code is part of the GNU C
94   |  **  Library, but also included in many other GNU distributions.  Compiling
95   |  **  and linking in this code is a waste when using the GNU C library
96   |  ** ( especially if it is a shared library).  Rather than having every GNU
97   |  **  program understand `configure --with-gnu-libc' and omit the object files,
98   |  **  it is simpler to just do this in the source for each such file. 
99   |  **
100  |  ** All this conditional nonsense has been commented out, because this
101  |  ** version of getopt has some module specific error handling that gets
102  |  ** tested during the check.  It's a nice sentiment, but it doesn't buy
103  |  ** you much to not include this code in.
104  |  **/
105  | 
106  | /**
107  |  **  This needs to come after some library #include
108  |  **  to get __GNU_LIBRARY__ defined. 
109  |  **/
110  | 
111  | /* #if defined( _LIBC) || !defined (__GNU_LIBRARY__) */
112  | 
113  | /**
114  |  **  Don't include stdlib.h for non-GNU C libraries because some of them
115  |  **  contain conflicting prototypes for getopt. 
116  |  **/
117  | 
118  | #  ifdef	__GNU_LIBRARY__
119  | #    include <stdlib.h>
120  | #  endif	/* GNU C library.  */
121  | 
122  | /**
123  |  **  This is for other GNU distributions with internationalized messages.
124  |  **  When compiling libc, the _ macro is predefined. 
125  |  **/
126  | 
127  | /*
128  | #  ifndef _
129  | #    ifdef HAVE_LIBINTL_H
130  | #     include <libintl.h>
131  | #     define _(msgid)	gettext( msgid)
132  | #    else
133  | #     define _(msgid)	(msgid)
134  | #    endif
135  | #  endif
136  | */
137  | 
138  | /**
139  |  **  This version of `getopt' appears to the caller like standard Unix `getopt'
140  |  **  but it behaves differently for the user, since it allows the user
141  |  **  to intersperse the options with the other arguments.
142  |  **
143  |  **  As `getopt' works, it permutes the elements of ARGV so that,
144  |  **  when it is done, all the options precede everything else.  Thus
145  |  **  all application programs are extended to handle flexible argument order.
146  |  **
147  |  **  Setting the environment variable POSIXLY_CORRECT disables permutation.
148  |  **  Then the behavior is completely standard.
149  |  **
150  |  **  GNU application programs can use a third alternative mode in which
151  |  **  they can distinguish the relative order of options and other arguments. 
152  |  **/
153  | 
154  | #  include "getopt.h"
155  | 
156  | /**
157  |  **  We want to avoid inclusion of string.h with non-GNU libraries
158  |  **  because there are many ways it can cause trouble.
159  |  **  On some systems, it contains special magic macros that don't work
160  |  **  in GCC. 
161  |  **/
162  | 
163  | #  ifdef	__GNU_LIBRARY__
164  | #    include <string.h>
165  | #    define	my_index	strchr
166  | #  else
167  | 
168  | /**
169  |  **  Avoid depending on library functions or files whose names are
170  |  **  inconsistent. 
171  |  **/
172  | 
173  | char *getenv();
174  | 
175  | static char *my_index( const char *str, int chr)
176  | {
177  |     while( *str) {
178  | 	if( *str == chr)
179  | 	    return( char *) str;
180  | 	str++;
181  |     }
182  |     return( 0);
183  | }
184  | 
185  | /**
186  |  **  If using GCC, we can safely declare strlen this way. 
187  |  **  If not using GCC, it is ok not to declare it. 
188  |  **
189  |  **  Note that Motorola Delta 68k R3V7 comes with GCC but not stddef.h.
190  |  **  That was relevant to code that was here before.
191  |  **/
192  | 
193  | #    ifdef __GNUC__
194  | #      if !defined( __STDC__) || !__STDC__
195  | 
196  | /**
197  |  **  gcc with -traditional declares the built-in strlen to return int,
198  |  **  and has done so at least since version 2.4.5. -- rms. 
199  |  **/
200  | 
201  | extern int strlen( const char *);
202  | #      endif /* not __STDC__ */
203  | #    endif /* __GNUC__ */
204  | 
205  | #  endif /* not __GNU_LIBRARY__ */
206  | 
207  | /**
208  |  **  Include the modules header in order to get all error messages
209  |  **/
210  | 
211  | #include "modules_def.h"
212  | 
213  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
214  | /** 				  LOCAL DATATYPES			     **/
215  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
216  | 
217  | /** not applicable **/
218  | 
219  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
220  | /** 				     CONSTANTS				     **/
221  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
222  | 
223  | /** not applicable **/
224  | 
225  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
226  | /**				      MACROS				     **/
227  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
228  | 
229  | /** not applicable **/
230  | 
231  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
232  | /** 				    GLOBAL DATA				     **/
233  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
234  | 
235  | /**
236  |  **  The following is required for compiling the TEST environment for the
237  |  **  modules package
238  |  **/
239  | 
240  | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
241  | #  ifdef	TEST
242  | char	*g_current_module = "getopt";
243  | int	linenum = 0;
244  | #  endif
245  | #endif /** _MODULES_DEF_H **/
246  | 
247  | /**
248  |  **  For communication from `getopt' to the caller.  When `getopt' finds an
249  |  **  option that takes an argument, the argument value is returned here.
250  |  **  Also, when `ordering' is RETURN_IN_ORDER, each non-option ARGV-element
251  |  **  is returned here. 
252  |  **/
253  | 
254  | char *optarg = NULL;
255  | 
256  | /**
257  |  **  Index in ARGV of the next element to be scanned.  This is used for
258  |  **  communication to and from the caller and for communication between
259  |  **  successive calls to `getopt'.
260  |  **
261  |  **  On entry to `getopt', zero means this is the first call; initialize.
262  |  **
263  |  **  When `getopt' returns EOF, this is the index of the first of the
264  |  **  non-option elements that the caller should itself scan.
265  |  **
266  |  **  Otherwise, `optind' communicates from one call to the next
267  |  **  how much of ARGV has been scanned so far. 
268  |  **/
269  | 
270  | /**
271  |  **  XXX 1003.2 says this must be 1 before any call. 
272  |  **/
273  | 
274  | int optind = 0;
275  | 
276  | /**
277  |  **  Callers store zero here to inhibit the error message for unrecognized
278  |  **  options. 
279  |  **/
280  | 
281  | int opterr = 1;
282  | 
283  | /**
284  |  **  Set to an option character which was unrecognized.
285  |  **  This must be initialized on some systems to avoid linking in the
286  |  **  system's own getopt implementation. 
287  |  **/
288  | 
289  | int optopt = '?';
290  | 
291  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
292  | /** 				    LOCAL DATA				     **/
293  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
294  | 
295  | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
296  | 
297  | /**
298  |  **  Runtime information for the modules package
299  |  **/
300  | 
301  | static	char	module_name[] = __FILE__;
302  | 
303  | #endif /** _MODULES_DEF_H **/
304  | 
305  | /**
306  |  **  The next char to be scanned in the option-element in which the last
307  |  **  option character we returned was found.  This allows us to pick up
308  |  **  the scan where we left off.
309  |  **
310  |  **  If this is zero, or a null string, it means resume the scan by advan-
311  |  **  cing to the next ARGV-element. 
312  |  **/
313  | 
314  | static char *nextchar;
315  | 
316  | /**
317  |  **  Describe how to deal with options that follow non-option ARGV-elements.
318  |  **
319  |  **  If the caller did not specify anything, the default is REQUIRE_ORDER if
320  |  **  the environment variable POSIXLY_CORRECT is defined, PERMUTE otherwise.
321  |  **
322  |  **  REQUIRE_ORDER means don't recognize them as options;
323  |  **  stop option processing when the first non-option is seen.
324  |  **  This is what Unix does.
325  |  **  This mode of operation is selected by either setting the environment
326  |  **  variable POSIXLY_CORRECT, or using `+' as the first character
327  |  **  of the list of option characters.
328  |  **
329  |  **  PERMUTE is the default.  We permute the contents of ARGV as we scan,
330  |  **  so that eventually all the non-options are at the end.  This allows options
331  |  **  to be given in any order, even with programs that were not written to
332  |  **  expect this.
333  |  **
334  |  **  RETURN_IN_ORDER is an option available to programs that were written
335  |  **  to expect options and other ARGV-elements in any order and that care about
336  |  **  the ordering of the two.  We describe each non-option ARGV-element
337  |  **  as if it were the argument of an option with character code 1.
338  |  **  Using `-' as the first character of the list of option characters
339  |  **  selects this mode of operation.
340  |  **
341  |  **  The special argument `--' forces an end of option-scanning regardless
342  |  **  of the value of `ordering'.  In the case of RETURN_IN_ORDER, only
343  |  **  `--' can cause `getopt' to return EOF with `optind' != ARGC. 
344  |  **/
345  | 
346  | static enum {
347  |     REQUIRE_ORDER, PERMUTE, RETURN_IN_ORDER
348  | } ordering;
349  | 
350  | /**
351  |  **  Value of POSIXLY_CORRECT environment variable. 
352  |  **/
353  | 
354  | static char *posixly_correct;
355  | 
356  | /**
357  |  **  Handle permutation of arguments. 
358  |  **/
359  | 
360  | /**
361  |  **  Describe the part of ARGV that contains non-options that have
362  |  **  been skipped.  `first_nonopt' is the index in ARGV of the first of them;
363  |  **  `last_nonopt' is the index after the last of them. 
364  |  **/
365  | 
366  | static int first_nonopt;
367  | static int last_nonopt;
368  | 
369  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
370  | /**				    PROTOTYPES				     **/
371  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
372  | 
373  | static void exchange( char **argv);
374  | static const char *_getopt_initialize( const char *optstring);
375  | static	int _getopt_internal(	int			 argc,
376  | 				char *const	 	*argv,
377  | 				const char	 	*optstring,
378  | 				const struct option	*longopts,
379  | 				int			*longind,
380  | 				int			 long_only);
381  | 
382  | /*++++
383  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
384  |  ** 									     **
385  |  **   Function:		exchange					     **
386  |  ** 									     **
387  |  **   Description:	Exchange two adjacent subsequences of ARGV.	     **
388  |  **			One subsequence is elements( first_nonopt,	     **
389  |  **			last_nonopt) which contains all the non-options that **
390  |  **			have been skipped so far. The other is elements	     **
391  |  **			(last_nonopt,optind), which contains all the options **
392  |  **			processed since those non-options were skipped.	     **
393  |  **									     **
394  |  **  			`first_nonopt' and `last_nonopt' are relocated so    **
395  |  **			that they describe the new indices of the non-options**
396  |  **			in ARGV after they are moved. 			     **
397  |  ** 									     **
398  |  **   First Edition:	1995/12/20					     **
399  |  ** 									     **
400  |  **   Parameters:	char	**argv		Command line arguments	     **
401  |  ** 									     **
402  |  **   Result:		argv		ARGV array with exchanged sequences  **
403  |  ** 									     **
404  |  **   Attached Globals:	first_nonopt	first and last non option argument   **
405  |  **			last_nonopt	on the stream before and after the   **
406  |  **					change.( I/O parameter)		     **
407  |  ** 									     **
408  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
409  |  ++++*/
410  | 
411  | static void exchange( char **argv)
412  | {
413  |     int bottom = first_nonopt;
414  |     int middle = last_nonopt;
415  |     int top = optind;
416  |     char *tem;
417  | 
418  |     /**
419  |      **  Exchange the shorter segment with the far end of the longer segment.
420  |      **  That puts the shorter segment into the right place.
421  |      **  It leaves the longer segment in the right place overall,
422  |      **  but it consists of two parts that need to be swapped next. 
423  |      **/
424  |     while( top > middle && middle > bottom) {
425  | 	if( top - middle > middle - bottom) {
426  | 
427  | 	    /**
428  | 	     ** Bottom segment is the short one. 
429  | 	     **/
430  | 
431  | 	    int len = middle - bottom;
432  | 	    register int i;
433  | 
434  | 	    /**
435  | 	     **  Swap it with the top part of the top segment. 
436  | 	     **/
437  | 
438  | 	    for( i = 0; i < len; i++) {
439  | 		tem = argv[bottom + i];
440  | 		argv[bottom + i] = argv[top -( middle - bottom) + i];
441  | 		argv[top -( middle - bottom) + i] = tem;
442  | 	    }
443  | 
444  | 	    /**
445  | 	     **  Exclude the moved bottom segment from further swapping. 
446  | 	     **/
447  | 
448  | 	    top -= len;
449  | 
450  | 	} else {
451  | 	    
452  | 	    /**
453  | 	     **  Top segment is the short one. 
454  | 	     **/
455  | 
456  | 	    int len = top - middle;
457  | 	    register int i;
458  | 
459  | 	    /**
460  | 	     **  Swap it with the bottom part of the bottom segment. 
461  | 	     **/
462  | 
463  | 	    for( i = 0; i < len; i++) {
464  | 		tem = argv[bottom + i];
465  | 		argv[bottom + i] = argv[middle + i];
466  | 		argv[middle + i] = tem;
467  | 	    }
468  | 
469  | 	    /**
470  | 	     **  Exclude the moved top segment from further swapping. 
471  | 	     **/
472  | 
473  | 	    bottom += len;
474  | 	}
475  | 
476  |     } /** while **/
477  | 
478  |     /**
479  |      **  Update records for the slots the non-options now occupy. 
480  |      **/
481  | 
482  |     first_nonopt +=( optind - last_nonopt);
483  |     last_nonopt = optind;
484  | 
485  | } /** end of 'exchange' **/
486  | 
487  | /*++++
488  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
489  |  ** 									     **
490  |  **   Function:		_getopt_initialize				     **
491  |  ** 									     **
492  |  **   Description:	Initialize the internal data when the first call is  **
493  |  **			made						     **
494  |  **			This defines how to proceed if options and non-op-   **
495  |  **			tions are mixed up. See definition of the enum       **
496  |  **			'ordering' for further explanation.		     **
497  |  ** 									     **
498  |  **   First Edition:	1995/12/20					     **
499  |  ** 									     **
500  |  **   Parameters:	char	*optstring	Options string		     **
501  |  ** 									     **
502  |  **   Result:		argv		ARGV array with exchanged sequences  **
503  |  **									     **
504  |  **   Attached globals: first_nonopt,		First an las position of     **
505  |  **			last_nonopt		non-option arguments	     **
506  |  **			optind			Option scan index	     **
507  |  **			nextchar		Next character to scan	     **
508  |  **			posixly_correct		Value of the environment     **
509  |  **						variable 'POSIXLY_CORRECT'   **
510  |  **			ordering		Ordering method ...	     **
511  |  ** 									     **
512  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
513  |  ++++*/
514  | 
515  | static const char *_getopt_initialize( const char *optstring)
516  | {
517  |     /**
518  |      **  Start processing options with ARGV-element 1( since ARGV-element 0
519  |      **  is the program name); the sequence of previously skipped
520  |      **  non-option ARGV-elements is empty. 
521  |      **/
522  | 
523  |     first_nonopt = last_nonopt = optind = 1;
524  |     nextchar = NULL;
525  |     posixly_correct = getenv( "POSIXLY_CORRECT");
526  | 
527  |     /**
528  |      **  Determine how to handle the ordering of options and nonoptions. 
529  |      **/
530  | 
531  |     if( optstring[0] == '-') {
532  | 	ordering = RETURN_IN_ORDER;
533  | 	++optstring;
534  | 
535  |     } else if( optstring[0] == '+') {
536  | 	ordering = REQUIRE_ORDER;
537  | 	++optstring;
538  | 
539  |     } else if( posixly_correct != NULL)
540  | 	ordering = REQUIRE_ORDER;
541  | 
542  |     else
543  | 	ordering = PERMUTE;
544  | 
545  |     return( optstring);
546  | 
547  | } /** End of '_getopt_initialize' **/
548  | 
549  | /*++++
550  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
551  |  ** 									     **
552  |  **   Function:		_getopt_internal				     **
553  |  ** 									     **
554  |  **   Description:	Scan elements of ARGV( whose length is ARGC) for     **
555  |  **			option characters given in OPTSTRING.	  	     **
556  |  **			or long-options specified in the longopt array	     **
557  |  ** 									     **
558  |  **   First Edition:	1995/12/20					     **
559  |  ** 									     **
560  |  **   Parameters:	int		  argc,		# of arguments	     **
561  |  **			char		**argv,		ARGV array	     **
562  |  **			char	 	 *optstring,	String of valid      **
563  |  **							short options	     **
564  |  **			struct option	 *longopts,	Table of valid long  **
565  |  **							options		     **
566  |  **			int		 *longind,	Returns the index of **
567  |  **							the found long opt.  **
568  |  **			int		  long_only	Search long options  **
569  |  **							only		     **
570  |  ** 									     **
571  |  **   Result:		int	'?'	Parse error			     **
572  |  **				0	Long option w/o argument found	     **
573  |  **				else	short option that has been found     **
574  |  **					or the value of a long option	     **
575  |  **				EOF	no more arguments on ARGV	     **
576  |  **									     **
577  |  **   Attached globals:	optind		Index of the current option in the   **
578  |  **					ARGV array			     **
579  |  **			optarg		Argument of an option with value     **
580  |  **									     **
581  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
582  |  ++++*/
583  | /** 									     **/
584  | /**   If an element of ARGV starts with '-', and is not exactly "-" or "--", **/
585  | /**   then it is an option element.  The characters of this element 	     **/
586  | /**   ( aside from the initial '-') are option characters.  If `getopt'      **/
587  | /**   is called repeatedly, it returns successively each of the option 	     **/
588  | /**   characters from each of the option elements. 			     **/
589  | /** 									     **/
590  | /**   If `getopt' finds another option character, it returns that character, **/
591  | /**   updating `optind' and `nextchar' so that the next call to `getopt' can **/
592  | /**   resume the scan with the following option character or ARGV-element.   **/
593  | /** 									     **/
594  | /**   If there are no more option characters, `getopt' returns `EOF'. 	     **/
595  | /**   Then `optind' is the index in ARGV of the first ARGV-element 	     **/
596  | /**   that is not an option. ( The ARGV-elements have been permuted 	     **/
597  | /**   so that those that are not options now come last.) 		     **/
598  | /** 									     **/
599  | /**   OPTSTRING is a string containing the legitimate option characters.     **/
600  | /**   If an option character is seen that is not listed in OPTSTRING, 	     **/
601  | /**   return '?' after printing an error message.  If you set `opterr' to    **/
602  | /**   zero, the error message is suppressed but we still return '?'. 	     **/
603  | /** 									     **/
604  | /**   If a char in OPTSTRING is followed by a colon, that means it wants an  **/
605  | /**   arg, so the following text in the same ARGV-element, or the text of    **/
606  | /**   the following ARGV-element, is returned in `optarg'.  Two colons mean  **/
607  | /**   an option that wants an optional arg; if there is text in the current  **/
608  | /**   ARGV-element, it is returned in `optarg', otherwise `optarg' is set to **/
609  | /**   zero. 								     **/
610  | /** 									     **/
611  | /**   If OPTSTRING starts with `-' or `+', it requests different methods of  **/
612  | /**   handling the non-option ARGV-elements. 				     **/
613  | /**   See the comments about RETURN_IN_ORDER and REQUIRE_ORDER, above. 	     **/
614  | /** 									     **/
615  | /**   Long-named options begin with `--' instead of `-'. 		     **/
616  | /**   Their names may be abbreviated as long as the abbreviation is unique   **/
617  | /**   or is an exact match for some defined option.  If they have an 	     **/
618  | /**   argument, it follows the option name in the same ARGV-element, 	     **/
619  | /**   separated from the option name by a `=', or else the in next ARGV-     **/
620  | /**   element.  When `getopt' finds a long-named option, it returns 0 if     **/
621  | /**   that option's `flag' field is nonzero, the value of the option's `val' **/
622  | /**   field if the `flag' field is zero. 				     **/
623  | /** 									     **/
624  | /**   The elements of ARGV aren't really const, because we permute them.     **/
625  | /**   But we pretend they're const in the prototype to be compatible 	     **/
626  | /**   with other systems. 						     **/
627  | /** 									     **/
628  | /**   LONGOPTS is a vector of `struct option' terminated by an 	  	     **/
629  | /**   element containing a name which is zero. 				     **/
630  | /** 									     **/
631  | /**   LONGIND returns the index in LONGOPT of the long-named option found.   **/
632  | /**   It is only valid when a long-named option has been found by the most   **/
633  | /**   recent call. 							     **/
634  | /** 									     **/
635  | /**   If LONG_ONLY is nonzero, '-' as well as '--' can introduce 	     **/
636  | /**   long-named options.  						     **/
637  | /** 									     **/
638  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
639  | 
640  | static	int _getopt_internal(	int			 argc,
641  | 				char *const	 	*argv,
642  | 				const char	 	*optstring,
643  | 				const struct option	*longopts,
644  | 				int			*longind,
645  | 				int			 long_only)
646  | {
647  |     optarg = NULL;
648  | 
649  |     /**
650  |      **  Initialization
651  |      **/
652  | 
653  |     if( optind == 0) {
654  | 	optstring = _getopt_initialize( optstring);
655  | 	optind = 1;		/** Don't scan ARGV[0], the program name.    **/
656  |     }
657  | 
658  |     if( nextchar == NULL || *nextchar == '\0') {
659  | 
660  | 	/**
661  | 	 **  Advance to the next ARGV-element.
662  | 	 **/
663  | 
664  | 	if( ordering == PERMUTE) {
665  | 
666  | 	    /**
667  | 	     **  If we have just processed some options following some non-
668  | 	     **  options, exchange them so that the options come first. 
669  | 	     **/
670  | 
671  | 	    if( first_nonopt != last_nonopt && last_nonopt != optind)
672  | 		exchange( (char **) argv);
673  | 	    else if( last_nonopt != optind)
674  | 		first_nonopt = optind;
675  | 
676  | 	    /**
677  | 	     **  Skip any additional non-options and extend the range of
678  | 	     **  non-options previously skipped. 
679  | 	     **/
680  | 
681  | 	    while( optind < argc &&
682  | 		  ( argv[optind][0] != '-' || argv[optind][1] == '\0'))
683  | 		optind++;
684  | 
685  | 	    last_nonopt = optind;
686  | 	}
687  | 
688  | 	/**
689  | 	 **  The special ARGV-element `--' means premature end of options.
690  | 	 **  Skip it like a null option, then exchange with previous non-
691  | 	 **  options **  as if it were an option, then skip everything else
692  | 	 **  like a non-option. 
693  | 	 **/
694  | 
695  | 	if( optind != argc && !strcmp( argv[optind], "--")) {
696  | 
697  | 	    optind++;
698  | 
699  | 	    if( first_nonopt != last_nonopt && last_nonopt != optind)
700  | 		exchange((char **) argv);
701  | 	    else if( first_nonopt == last_nonopt)
702  | 		first_nonopt = optind;
703  | 
704  | 	    last_nonopt = argc;
705  | 
706  | 	    optind = argc;
707  | 	}
708  | 
709  | 	/**
710  | 	 **  If we have done all the ARGV-elements, stop the scan and back
711  | 	 **  over any non-options that we skipped and permuted. 
712  | 	 **/
713  | 
714  | 	if( optind == argc) {
715  | 
716  | 	    /**
717  | 	     **  Set the next-arg-index to point at the non-options that we
718  | 	     **  previously skipped, so the caller will digest them. 
719  | 	     **/
720  | 
721  | 	    if( first_nonopt != last_nonopt)
722  | 		optind = first_nonopt;
723  | 
724  | 	    return( EOF);
725  | 	}
726  | 
727  | 	/**
728  | 	 **  If we have come to a non-option and did not permute it,
729  | 	 **  either stop the scan or describe it to the caller and pass it by. 
730  | 	 **/
731  | 
732  | 	if( argv[optind][0] != '-' || argv[optind][1] == '\0') {
733  | 
734  | 	    if( ordering == REQUIRE_ORDER)
735  | 		return EOF;
736  | 	    optarg = argv[optind++];
737  | 
738  | 	    return( 1);
739  | 	}
740  | 
741  | 	/**
742  | 	 **  We have found another option-ARGV-element. 
743  | 	 **  Skip the initial punctuation. 
744  | 	 **/
745  | 
746  | 	nextchar =( argv[optind] + 1 +
747  | 	   ( longopts != NULL && argv[optind][1] == '-'));
748  |     }
749  | 
750  |     /**
751  |      **    Decode the current option-ARGV-element. 
752  |      **/
753  | 
754  |     /**
755  |      **  Check whether the ARGV-element is a long option.
756  |      **
757  |      **  If long_only and the ARGV-element has the form "-f", where f is
758  |      **  a valid short option, don't consider it an abbreviated form of
759  |      **  a long option that starts with f.  Otherwise there would be no
760  |      **  way to give the -f short option.
761  |      **
762  |      **  On the other hand, if there's a long option "fubar" and
763  |      **  the ARGV-element is "-fu", do consider that an abbreviation of
764  |      **  the long option, just like "--fu", and not "-f" with arg "u".
765  |      **
766  |      **  This distinction seems to be the most useful approach. 
767  |      **/
768  | 
769  |     if( longopts != NULL &&( argv[optind][1] == '-'     ||
770  |        (  long_only &&
771  | 	 (  argv[optind][2] || !my_index (optstring, argv[optind][1]))))) {
772  | 
773  | 	char *nameend;
774  | 	const struct option *p;
775  | 	const struct option *pfound = NULL;
776  | 	int exact = 0;
777  | 	int ambig = 0;
778  | 	int indfound;
779  | 	int option_index;
780  | 
781  | 	/**
782  | 	 **  Skip the remaining characters of the long option upt to its
783  | 	 **  names end( End of the option itsself or the '=' sign)
784  | 	 **/
785  | 
786  | 	for( nameend = nextchar; *nameend && *nameend != '='; nameend++);
787  | 
788  | 	/**
789  | 	 **  Test all long options for either exact match or abbreviated
790  | 	 **  matches.
791  | 	 **/
792  | 
793  | 	for( p = longopts, option_index = 0; p->name; p++, option_index++) {
794  | 	    if( !strncmp( p->name, nextchar, nameend - nextchar)) {
795  | 
796  | 		if( nameend - nextchar == strlen( p->name)) {
797  | 
798  | 		    /**
799  | 		     ** Exact match found. 
800  | 		     **/
801  | 
802  | 		    pfound = p;
803  | 		    indfound = option_index;
804  | 		    exact = 1;
805  | 		    break;
806  | 
807  | 		} else if( pfound == NULL) {
808  | 
809  | 		    /**
810  | 		     **  First nonexact match found.
811  | 		     **/
812  | 
813  | 		    pfound = p;
814  | 		    indfound = option_index;
815  | 
816  | 		} else
817  | 
818  | 		    /**
819  | 		     **  Second or later nonexact match found. 
820  | 		     **/
821  | 
822  | 		    ambig = 1;
823  | 
824  | 	    } /** if( !strncmp) **/
825  | 	} /** for **/
826  | 
827  | 	/**
828  | 	 **  Print an error message for ambigious abbreviations and exit
829  | 	 **  on error
830  | 	 **/
831  | 
832  | 	if( ambig && !exact) {
833  | 
834  | 	    if( opterr)
835  | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
836  | 		ErrorLogger( ERR_OPT_AMBIG, LOC, argv[optind], NULL);
837  | #else
838  | 		fprintf( stderr, _("%s: option `%s' is ambiguous\n"),
839  | 		    argv[0], argv[optind]);
840  | #endif
841  | 
842  | 	    nextchar += strlen( nextchar);
843  | 	    optind++;
844  | 	    return( '?');
845  | 	}
846  | 
847  | 	/**
848  | 	 **  Longname found ?
849  | 	 **/
850  | 
851  | 	if( pfound != NULL) {
852  | 
853  | 	    option_index = indfound;
854  | 	    optind++;
855  | 
856  | 	    /**
857  | 	     **  *nameend is != NULL if there is a value specified for
858  | 	     **  the option: '--option=value' -> *nameend = '='
859  | 	     **/
860  | 
861  | 	    if( *nameend) {
862  | 
863  | 		/**
864  | 		 **  Don't test has_arg with >, because some C compilers don't
865  | 		 **  allow it to be used on enums. 
866  | 		 **/
867  | 
868  | 		if( pfound->has_arg)
869  | 		    optarg = nameend + 1;
870  | 
871  | 		else {
872  | 		    	  
873  | 		    if( opterr) {
874  | 
875  | 			/**
876  | 			 **  ERROR: --option w/o argument
877  | 			 **/
878  | 
879  | 			if( argv[optind - 1][1] == '-')
880  | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
881  | 			    ErrorLogger( ERR_OPT_NOARG, LOC, pfound->name, NULL);
882  | #else
883  | 			    fprintf( stderr,
884  | 				_("%s: option `--%s' doesn't allow an argument\n"),
885  | 				argv[0], pfound->name);
886  | #endif
887  | 
888  | 			/**
889  | 			 **  ERROR: +option or -option w/o argument
890  | 			 **/
891  | 
892  | 			} else {
893  | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
894  | 			    char buffer[ BUFSIZ];
895  | 			    sprintf( buffer, "%c%s", argv[optind - 1][0], pfound->name);
896  | 			    ErrorLogger( ERR_OPT_NOARG, LOC, buffer, NULL);
897  | #else
898  | 			    fprintf( stderr,
899  | 				_("%s: option `%c%s' doesn't allow an argument\n"),
900  | 				argv[0], argv[optind - 1][0], pfound->name);
901  | #endif
902  | 			}
903  | 
904  | 		    nextchar += strlen( nextchar);
905  | 		    return( '?');
906  | 		}
907  | 
908  | 	    /**
909  | 	     **  Options with arguments
910  | 	     **/
911  | 
912  | 	    } else if( pfound->has_arg == 1) {
913  | 
914  | 		if( optind < argc)
915  | 		    optarg = argv[optind++];
916  | 
917  | 		else {
918  | 
919  | 		    /**
920  | 		     **  ERROR: Option without argument where one is required
921  | 		     **/
922  | 
923  | 		    if( opterr)
924  | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
925  | 			ErrorLogger( ERR_OPT_REQARG, LOC, argv[optind-1], NULL);
926  | #else
927  | 			fprintf( stderr,
928  | 			    _("%s: option `%s' requires an argument\n"),
929  | 			    argv[0], argv[optind - 1]);
930  | #endif
931  | 
932  | 		    nextchar += strlen( nextchar);
933  | 		    return((optstring[0] == ':') ? ':' : '?');
934  | 		}
935  | 	    }
936  | 
937  | 	    /** 
938  | 	     **  Return the indication, that a long vlaue has been found
939  | 	     **  and set up pointers for the next option expansion
940  | 	     **/
941  | 
942  | 	    nextchar += strlen( nextchar);
943  | 
944  | 	    if( longind != NULL)
945  | 		*longind = option_index;
946  | 
947  | 	    if( pfound->flag) {
948  | 		*(pfound->flag) = pfound->val;
949  | 		return( 0);
950  | 	    }
951  | 	    return( pfound->val);
952  | 	}
953  | 
954  | 	/**
955  | 	 **  Can't find it as a long option.  If this is not getopt_long_only,
956  | 	 **  or the option starts with '--' or is not a valid short
957  | 	 **  option, then it's an error.
958  | 	 **  Otherwise interpret it as a short option. 
959  | 	 **/
960  | 
961  | 	if( !long_only || argv[optind][1] == '-' ||
962  | 	    my_index( optstring, *nextchar) == NULL) {
963  | 
964  | 	    if( opterr) {
965  | 
966  | 		/**
967  | 		 ** ERROR: unrecognized --option 
968  | 		 **/
969  | 
970  | 		if( argv[optind][1] == '-') {
971  | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
972  | 		    ErrorLogger( ERR_OPT_UNKNOWN, LOC, nextchar, NULL);
973  | #else
974  | 		    fprintf( stderr, _("%s: unrecognized option `--%s'\n"),
975  | 			argv[0], nextchar);
976  | #endif
977  | 
978  | 		/**
979  | 		 ** ERROR: unrecognized +option or -option
980  | 		 **/
981  | 
982  | 		} else {
983  | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
984  | 		    char buffer[ BUFSIZ];
985  | 		    sprintf( buffer, "%c%s", argv[optind][0], nextchar);
986  | 		    ErrorLogger( ERR_OPT_AMBIG, LOC, buffer, NULL);
987  | #else
988  | 		    fprintf( stderr, _("%s: unrecognized option `%c%s'\n"),
989  | 			argv[0], argv[optind][0], nextchar);
990  | #endif
991  | 		}
992  | 	    }
993  | 
994  | 	    nextchar =( char *) "";
995  | 	    optind++;
996  | 	    return( '?');
997  | 	}
998  |     } /** if( long option) **/
999  | 
1000 |     /**
1001 |      **  Look at and handle the next short option-character. 
1002 |      **/
1003 | 
1004 |     {
1005 | 	char c = *nextchar++;
1006 | 	char *temp = my_index( optstring, c);
1007 | 
1008 | 	/**
1009 | 	 **  Increment `optind' when we start to process its last character. 
1010 | 	 **/
1011 | 
1012 | 	if( *nextchar == '\0')
1013 | 	    ++optind;
1014 | 
1015 | 	/**
1016 | 	 **  Unrecognized options
1017 | 	 **/
1018 | 
1019 | 	if( temp == NULL || c == ':') {
1020 | 	    if( opterr) {
1021 | 
1022 | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
1023 | 		    char buffer[ 2];
1024 | 		    buffer[ 0] = c;
1025 | 		    buffer[ 1] = '\0';
1026 | #endif
1027 | 
1028 | 		if( posixly_correct) {
1029 | 
1030 | 		    /**
1031 | 		     **  1003.2 specifies the format of this message. 
1032 | 		     **/
1033 | 
1034 | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
1035 | 		    ErrorLogger( ERR_OPT_ILL, LOC, buffer, NULL);
1036 | #else
1037 | 		    fprintf( stderr, _("%s: illegal option -- %c\n"),
1038 | 			argv[0], c);
1039 | #endif
1040 | 		} else {
1041 | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
1042 | 		    ErrorLogger( ERR_OPT_INV, LOC, buffer, NULL);
1043 | #else
1044 | 		    fprintf( stderr, _("%s: invalid option -- %c\n"),
1045 | 			argv[0], c);
1046 | #endif
1047 | 		}
1048 | 	    }
1049 | 	    optopt = c;
1050 | 	    return( '?');
1051 | 	}
1052 | 
1053 | 	/**
1054 | 	 **
1055 | 	 **/
1056 | 
1057 | 	if( temp[1] == ':') {
1058 | 	    if( temp[2] == ':') {
1059 | 
1060 | 		/**
1061 | 		 **  This is an option that accepts an argument optionally.
1062 | 		 **/
1063 | 
1064 | 		if( *nextchar != '\0') {
1065 | 		    optarg = nextchar;
1066 | 		    optind++;
1067 | 		} else
1068 | 		    optarg = NULL;
1069 | 
1070 | 		nextchar = NULL;
1071 | 
1072 | 	    } else {	/** optional argument **/
1073 | 
1074 | 		/**
1075 | 		 **  This is an option that requires an argument. 
1076 | 		 **/
1077 | 
1078 | 		if( *nextchar != '\0') {
1079 | 		    optarg = nextchar;
1080 | 
1081 | 		    /**
1082 | 		     **  If we end this ARGV-element by taking the rest as an arg,
1083 | 		     **  we must advance to the next element now. 
1084 | 		     **/
1085 | 
1086 | 		    optind++;
1087 | 
1088 | 		} else if( optind == argc) {
1089 | 
1090 | 		    if( opterr) {
1091 | 
1092 | 			/**
1093 | 			 **  1003.2 specifies the format of this message. *
1094 | 			 **/
1095 | 
1096 | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
1097 | 			char buffer[ 2];
1098 | 			buffer[ 0] = c;
1099 | 			buffer[ 1] = '\0';
1100 | 			ErrorLogger( ERR_OPT_REQARG, LOC, buffer, NULL);
1101 | #else
1102 | 			fprintf( stderr,
1103 | 			    _("%s: option requires an argument -- %c\n"),
1104 | 				argv[0], c);
1105 | #endif
1106 | 		    }
1107 | 
1108 | 		    optopt = c;
1109 | 		    if( optstring[0] == ':')
1110 | 			c = ':';
1111 | 		    else
1112 | 			c = '?';
1113 | 
1114 | 		} else
1115 | 
1116 | 		    /**
1117 | 		     **  We already incremented `optind' once;
1118 | 		     **  increment it again when taking next ARGV-elt as argument.
1119 | 		     **/
1120 | 
1121 | 		    optarg = argv[optind++];
1122 | 		    nextchar = NULL;
1123 | 	    }
1124 | 	}
1125 | 
1126 | 	/**
1127 | 	 **  Now c contains the found character in case of success of '?' in case
1128 | 	 **  of failure
1129 | 	 **/
1130 | 
1131 | 	return( c);
1132 | 
1133 |     } /** block **/
1134 | 
1135 | } /** End of '_getopt_internal' **/
1136 | 
1137 | /*++++
1138 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
1139 |  ** 									     **
1140 |  **   Function:		getopt, getopt_long, getopt_long_only		     **
1141 |  ** 									     **
1142 |  **   Description:	Calls _getopt_internal in order to provide a normal  **
1143 |  **			getopt call.					     **
1144 |  ** 									     **
1145 |  **   First Edition:	1995/12/20					     **
1146 |  ** 									     **
1147 |  **   Parameters:	int	  argc,		# of arguments		     **
1148 |  **			char	**argv,		ARGV array		     **
1149 |  **			char 	 *optstring,	String of valid short opt.   **
1150 |  ** 									     **
1151 |  **   Result:		int	'?'	Parse error			     **
1152 |  **				0	Long option w/o argument found	     **
1153 |  **				else	short option that has been found     **
1154 |  **					or the value of a long option	     **
1155 |  **				EOF	no more arguments on ARGV	     **
1156 |  **									     **
1157 |  **   Attached globals:	optind		Index of the current option in the   **
1158 |  **					ARGV array			     **
1159 |  **			optarg		Argument of an option with value     **
1160 |  **			opterr		Set in case of parse errors	     **
1161 |  **									     **
1162 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
1163 |  ++++*/
1164 | 
1165 | int getopt( int argc, char *const *argv, const char *optstring)
1166 | {
1167 |     return _getopt_internal( argc, argv, optstring,
1168 | 			     ( const struct option *) 0,
1169 | 			     ( int *) 0,
1170 | 			      0);
1171 | } /** End of 'getopt' **/
1172 | 
1173 | int getopt_long( int argc, char *const *argv, const char *optstring,
1174 | 		 const struct option *longopts, int *longind)
1175 | {
1176 |     return _getopt_internal( argc, argv, optstring, longopts, longind, 0);
1177 | 
1178 | } /** End of 'getopt' **/
1179 | 
1180 | int getopt_long_only( int argc, char *const *argv, const char *optstring,
1181 | 		      const struct option *longopts, int *longind)
1182 | {
1183 |     return _getopt_internal( argc, argv, optstring, longopts, longind, 1);
1184 | 
1185 | } /** End of 'getopt' **/
1186 | 
1187 | /* #endif	*/ /* _LIBC or not __GNU_LIBRARY__.  */
1188 | 
1189 | #ifdef TEST
1190 | 
1191 | /*++++
1192 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
1193 |  ** 									     **
1194 |  **   Function:		main						     **
1195 |  ** 									     **
1196 |  **   Description:	Test procedure for getopt			     **
1197 |  **			Compile with -DTEST to make an executable for use in **
1198 |  **			testing the above definition of `getopt'	     **
1199 |  ** 									     **
1200 |  **   First Edition:	1995/12/20					     **
1201 |  ** 									     **
1202 |  **   Parameters:	int	  argc,		# of arguments		     **
1203 |  **			char	**argv,		ARGV array		     **
1204 |  ** 									     **
1205 |  **   Result:		-						     **
1206 |  **									     **
1207 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
1208 |  ++++*/
1209 | 
1210 | int main( int argc, char **argv)
1211 | {
1212 |     int c;
1213 |     int digit_optind = 0;
1214 |     int longind;
1215 |     int option, verbose;
1216 |     char *value;
1217 | 
1218 |     const struct option longopts[] = {
1219 | 	{ "test", no_argument, NULL, 0 },
1220 | 	{ "option", optional_argument, &option, 1 },
1221 | 	{ "verbose", optional_argument, NULL, 'v' },
1222 | 	{ "value", required_argument, NULL, 'x'},
1223 | 	{ NULL, no_argument, NULL, 0 }
1224 |     };
1225 | 
1226 |     /**
1227 |      **  Print all options ...
1228 |      **/
1229 | 
1230 |     while( 1) {
1231 | 
1232 | 	int this_option_optind = optind ? optind : 1;
1233 | 
1234 | 	c = getopt_long( argc, argv, "abc:d:0123456789", longopts, &longind);
1235 | 	if( c == EOF)
1236 | 	    break;  /** while( 1) **/
1237 | 
1238 | 	switch( c) {
1239 | 
1240 | 	    case 0:
1241 | 		printf( "option --test or --option\n");
1242 | 		if( optarg)
1243 | 		    printf( "with argument '%s'", optarg);
1244 | 		printf( "\n   option is set to %d\n", option);
1245 | 		break;
1246 | 
1247 | 	    case '0':
1248 | 	    case '1':
1249 | 	    case '2':
1250 | 	    case '3':
1251 | 	    case '4':
1252 | 	    case '5':
1253 | 	    case '6':
1254 | 	    case '7':
1255 | 	    case '8':
1256 | 	    case '9':
1257 | 		if( digit_optind != 0 && digit_optind != this_option_optind)
1258 | 		    printf( "digits occur in two different argv-elements.\n");
1259 | 		digit_optind = this_option_optind;
1260 | 		    printf( "option %c\n", c);
1261 | 		break;
1262 | 
1263 | 	    case 'a':
1264 | 		printf( "option a\n");
1265 | 		break;
1266 | 
1267 | 	    case 'b':
1268 | 		printf( "option b\n");
1269 | 		break;
1270 | 
1271 | 	    case 'c':
1272 | 		printf( "option c with value `%s'\n", optarg);
1273 | 		break;
1274 | 
1275 | 	    case 'v':
1276 | 	    case 'x':
1277 | 		printf( "option %c ", c);
1278 | 		if( optarg)
1279 | 		    printf( "with argument '%s'", optarg);
1280 | 		printf( "\n");
1281 | 		break;
1282 | 
1283 | 	    case '?':
1284 | 		break;
1285 | 
1286 | 	    default:
1287 | 		printf( "?? getopt returned character code 0%o ??\n", c);
1288 | 	}
1289 |     }  /** while( 1) **/
1290 | 
1291 |     /**
1292 |      **  Finally print all remaining arguments
1293 |      **/
1294 | 
1295 |     if( optind < argc) {
1296 | 	printf( "non-option ARGV-elements: ");
1297 | 	while( optind < argc)
1298 | 	    printf( "%s ", argv[optind++]);
1299 | 	printf( "\n");
1300 |     }
1301 | 
1302 |     /**
1303 |      **  Exit on success
1304 |      **/
1305 | 
1306 |     exit( 0);
1307 | 
1308 | } /** End of 'main' **/
1309 | 
1310 | #endif /* TEST */
